linkTarget.anchoringText: Figures: 1, 2 and table 1 illustrate a geological overview of subject reservoir.
Figures: 1, 2 and table 1 illustrate a geological overview of subject reservoir.

Later in 1996, unsuccessful trial was made to revive the production from layer X1 through long string, in which a 2.31″ ‘FWG’ plug was set at the 2.31″ ‘F 'nipple and punched long string above the plug. In 2002 the wells was killed and secured with plugs. Since then water flooding had been advanced in reservoir X1 supported by water injection as demonstrated in following figure #3, 4 & 5

In 2002 the wells was killed and secured with plugs. Since then water flooding had been advanced in reservoir X1 supported by water injection as demonstrated in following figure #3, 4 & 5
Figure#6 provides the summary of reservoir evaluation for the subject well, where the simulation results show that the well is unable to produce when completed as normal deviated well.

image-wrap.caption: "Reservoir Evaluation overview at the sidetrack feasible location"

linkTarget.anchoringText: It was believed that, this section was essentially against the dense zone, which separates the ADMA-OPCO reservoirs from the overlaying high pressure reservoirs. Moreover the presence of one hundred ft good cement below the deepest porous section was anticipated to act as a barrier between the two reservoirs, which would ultimately prevent flow behind casing as illustrated in below figure #10 & 11.

image-wrap.label: Figure #10
image-wrap.caption: Bottom 100 ft accessible of 7" CSG Cement Evaluation Section

formatted-caption.caption-text: Bottom 100 ft accessible of 7" CSG Cement Evaluation Section

linkTarget.anchoringText: It was believed that, this section was essentially against the dense zone, which separates the ADMA-OPCO reservoirs from the overlaying high pressure reservoirs. Moreover the presence of one hundred ft good cement below the deepest porous section was anticipated to act as a barrier between the two reservoirs, which would ultimately prevent flow behind casing as illustrated in below figure #10 & 11.

image-wrap.label: Figure #11
image-wrap.caption: Open Hole Log Interpretation of 6" pilot hole

formatted-caption.caption-text: Open Hole Log Interpretation of 6" pilot hole

linkTarget.anchoringText: Similar to the previous situation of 6" hole; WBT failed the negative test, where some leak was observed; however, positive test held good. All the effort spent to improve injectivity prior to remedial job was unsuccessful. The decision was taken to condition the mud weight to control the well and to complete the drilling of planned 2000 ft 6" horizontal drain at the top of reservoir only, as illustrated in figure #12. The most probably reason behind this situation was the presence of a localized porous section within the dense formation (isolating two reservoirs). This porous section is under appraisal phase.

image-wrap.label: Figure #13
image-wrap.caption: Caliber log across 2000 ft of 6" Hz drain

formatted-caption.caption-text: Caliber log across 2000 ft of 6" Hz drain

linkTarget.anchoringText: The configuration of 4 1/2" liner and PKRs are illustarted in figures 14, 15 & 16.
The configuration of 4 1/2" liner and PKRs are illustarted in figures 14, 15 & 16.
The configuration of 4 1/2" liner and PKRs are illustarted in figures 14, 15 & 16.

The well has been online successfully after post rig stimulation with healthy oil i.e. no WC and normal associated GOR. Both, the production data and the bottom hole pressure survey confirmed the integrity of 41/2" liner i.e. no inter reservoir communication from the overlaying pressurized reservoir. Figures 17 & 18 illustrated production performance and reservoir pressure bubble map of offset wells producing from layer "X1".

The well has been online successfully after post rig stimulation with healthy oil i.e. no WC and normal associated GOR.
